column1: A blood test can be done to see how much of this protein you have in your blood.
A lack of this protein or problem with the function of this protein may cause blood clots to form in veins.
The test is also used to screen relatives of persons who are known to have protein S deficiency.
A lack (deficiency) of protein S can lead to excess clotting.

It can also develop due to pregnancy or certain diseases, including: - Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active (disseminated intravascular coagulation) - HIV infection - Liver disease - Long-term antibiotic use - Warfarin (Coumadin) use A problem such as a sudden blood clot in the lung may reduce the protein S level.
